dtype.description: @varchar(nnn): a varying-length string of length <= nnn
signed floating point types using 32 bits
signed floating point types using 64 bits
a Warehouse Identifier (a number that is unique throughout the Warehouse)
@number(precision,scale): any number for which exact precision is preserved.
a boolean value: 'T' for true and 'F' for false

ttype.name: state
ttype.comment: Tables that are used to define the Warehouse contents and its current state.

ttype.name: independent
ttype.comment: Tables that contain universally- or widely-accepted scientific data. These tables are independent of any dataset.

ttype.name: object
ttype.comment: Tables that represent the principal objects in the Warehouse. All object tables have a WID column that is globally unique identifier, and a DataSetWID column that refers to the DataSet row of the dataset that loaded the object.

ttype.name: arbitrary-relation
ttype.comment: Tables that implement arbitrary relations among Warehouse objects. Naming convention is to use /table/WID as a column name for any WID referencing an object from /table/.

ttype.name: object-descriptor
ttype.comment: Tables that reference an untyped WID (one that could be from one of several object tables). Naming convention is to use OtherWID as a column name for the untyped WID.

ttype.name: associative
ttype.comment: Tables that (only) link WIDs from two object tables. These tables implement many-many relations between Warehouse objects. Naming convention is /table1/WID/table2/WID.

table.name: Warehouse
table.comment: Describes this version of the BioSPICE Warehouse.
This table contains exactly one row.

column.name: Version
column.comment: Numbered version of the warehouse schema that is loaded

column.name: LoadDate
column.comment: Date that this schema was loaded

column.name: MaxSpecialWID
column.comment: Maximum value allowed for SpecialWIDTable.PreviousWID / specialWID sequence

column.name: MaxReservedWID
column.comment: Maximum value allowed for reserved WIDs (regulard WIDs start above this WID number)

column.name: Description
column.comment: Free-form text as desired by the warehouse maintainers

schema.command: INSERT INTO Warehouse (Version, LoadDate, MaxSpecialWID, MaxReservedWID) VALUES (4.5, now(), 999, 999999);
INSERT INTO Warehouse (Version, LoadDate, MaxSpecialWID, MaxReservedWID) VALUES (4.5, sysdate, 999, 999999);

sequence.name: WID_sequence
sequence.comment: Generate a unlimited sequence of unique numbers to do the bookkeeping for
Warehouse ID (WID) numbers, which serve as keys for all Warehouse entities.
WIDs 0 and 1 are reserved and not allocated.
Oracle dataset loaders use the following SQL for WID assignment:
using an INTO clause in some APIs to store the result in a variable.

table.name: WIDTable
table.comment: To allow for compatibility with RDBMS systems that do not support
sequences, this table may be used to store the last used WID.
MySQL dataset loaders use the following SQL for WID assignment:
DELETE FROM WIDTable;
INSERT INTO WIDTable VALUES ();
SELECT last_insert_id();
It may also be used in RDBMS systems that do not support auto-increment
of a counter; however additional protocol like table locking may be
needed to assure the integrity of WIDs during concurrent assignment.
This table contains exactly one row at any given time.

column.name: PreviousWID
column.comment: Last-used Warehouse identifier.

sequence.name: SpecialWID_sequence
sequence.comment: Generate a finite sequence of WIDs for use as special Warehouse entities,
including DataSet WIDs. These are small integers.

table.name: SpecialWIDTable
table.comment: Special WIDs are low-valued WIDs, assigned to globally and frequently used
WIDs within a dataset, such as its DataSetWID. They are both more
mnemonic, and potentially more efficient to store. Warehouse.MaxSpecialWID
delimits special and regular WIDs.
Analogous to WIDTable, this table is used to allocate special WIDs.
MySQL dataset loaders use the following protocol for WID assignment:
DELETE FROM SpecialWIDTable;
INSERT INTO SpecialWIDTable VALUES ();
SELECT last_insert_id();
This table contains exactly one row at any given time.

column.name: PreviousWID
column.comment: Last-used special WID

table.name: Enumeration
table.comment: This table defines enumerated types used within the warehouse. Essentially,
enumerated types correspond to small controlled vocabularies used within
one or more warehouse tables. For example, the warehouse table Feature has
a column called Type that defines the type of a feature within an amino-acid
sequence. Examples types might be PHOS-RESIDUE and GLY-RESIDUE, corresponding
to residues in a protein that are phosphorylated and glycosylated, respectively.
Those two enumerated types would be entered into two rows of this Enumeration
table. Note that in some cases the values actually stored in the warehouse
table are numbers, which are stored in the Value field of the Enumeration table
as the string form of that number.

column.name: TableName
column.comment: Table this enumeration is used in

column.name: ColumnName
column.comment: Column this enumeration is used in

column.name: Value
column.comment: The enumeration value

column.name: Meaning
column.comment: A comment describing its meaning

table.name: DataSet
table.comment: Table whose rows define each dataset currently loaded into the warehouse.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entry.

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name of the database.

column.name: Version
column.comment: Version of the database described by this warehouse dataset; in practice, this can be populated
with whatever the user chooses to put in it from the command line arguments

column.name: ReleaseDate
column.comment: Date that the original database was first released.

column.name: LoadDate
column.comment: Date that the load of this data set into the warehouse began.

column.name: ChangeDate
column.comment: Date of the last change to this dataset, or the date the load
completed if no changes have occurred. NULL means that the
is currently loading, or a fatal error occurred on the load.
NOTE: This feature is not supported by most loaders until version 4.0.

column.name: HomeURL
column.comment: Web address of the home page of the original database.

column.name: QueryURL
column.comment: A URL at which we can retrieve objects in this database via the WWW
by substituting the unique ID of the object we wish to retrieve for the
string "%s" in the query URL. An example URL is:
http://database.university.edu/get-object/5050%s

column.name: LoadedBy
column.comment: The name (or username) of the person who loaded this dataset.
NOTE: This feature is not supported by most loaders until
version 4.0. At that time, this column should be required.

column.name: Application
column.comment: The name of the application that created this dataset.
NOTE: This feature is not supported by most loaders until
version 4.0. At that time, this column should be required.

column.name: ApplicationVersion
column.comment: The version of the application that created this dataset.
NOTE: This feature is not supported by most loaders until
version 4.0. At that time, this column should be required.

table.name: DataSetHierarchy
table.comment: Defines a dataset containment hierarchy. If a dataset contains another, either directly or indirectly, a row exists for that dataset pair in this table. A dataset always contains itself; therefore each dataset is included in at least one row in this table. A dataset may contain any number of datasets, and be contained in any number of datasets. To query for an object in a containing dataset whose datasetwid is NN, regardless of which contained dataset it is in, use a query like the following:
select wid from DataSetHierarchy h, Protein p where h.superwid=NN and h.subwid=p.datasetwid and p.name='some name'

column.name: SuperWID
column.comment: Reference to the containing DataSet.

column.name: SubWID
column.comment: Reference to the contained DataSet.

table.name: Entry
table.comment: Defines metadata describing a warehouse object.
Every warehouse object (that is, anything with a WID column) must have an associated Entry row.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: Warehouse ID of the entity

column.name: InsertDate
column.comment: Date entity was stored in the warehouse

column.name: CreationDate
column.comment: Date entity was created in its source dataset

column.name: ModifiedDate
column.comment: Date that the entry was last modified, either
in the warehouse or in the source dataset

column.name: LoadError
column.comment: 'T' if an error (eg. parse error on some field of the entry)
occured during loading of this entry into the warehouse, else 'F'.

column.name: LineNumber
column.comment: Either line number or entry number from dataset source file

column.name: ErrorMessage
column.comment: Message describing error, if any

column.name: DatasetWID
column.comment: The dataset the entity is from

table.name: GeneExpressionData
table.comment: MAGE gene expression data (BioDataCube)

This table definition may evolve as the requirements for gene expression data are better understood. The MAGE OM currently allows 'any' type for the Value component of the BioDataCube. We are investigating ways to make this table better accomodate the variety of allowed datatypes. Please send suggestions to support@biowarehouse.org

column.name: B
column.comment: BioAssay index

column.name: D
column.comment: DesignElement index

column.name: Q
column.comment: Quantitation Type index

column.name: Value
column.comment: Data value. See associated QuantiatitationType obect for type information.

column.name: BioAssayValuesWID
column.comment: The BioAssayValues object the entity is from

table.name: Element
table.comment: The periodic table of elements

column.name: WID
column.comment: WID of this element

column.name: Name
column.comment: Long name (e.g. 'Oxygen')

column.name: ElementSymbol
column.comment: Symbol (e.g. 'O')

column.name: AtomicWeight
column.comment: Weighted average weight (e.g. 16.x)

column.name: AtomicNumber
column.comment: Number of protons

table.name: Valence
table.comment: Defines one or more valences for each element.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: WID of the element

column.name: Valence
column.comment: Number of valence electrons

table.name: LightSource
table.comment: Defines a light source, e.g., as produced by a scientific instrument. Used by flow cytometry in describing the cytometry instrument.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse idetification number for this light source

column.name: Wavelength
column.comment: Wavelength of the light emitted, in nanometers

column.name: Type
column.comment: Enumeration. Specifies the type of light source (arc lamp, a particular laser, etc.).

restriction.description: A type of light source
An ion laser that uses argon gas to produce light
An ion laser that uses krypton gas to produce light
An ion laser that uses a combination of krypton and argon gases to produce light
A laser that uses helium and neon gases to produce light

column.name: InstrumentWID
column.comment: WID of the object representing the instrument producing the light. For a flow cytometry experiment, this is typically a reference to a Parameterizable row defining the cytometry instrument used. This instrument is instantiated as a ParameterizableApplication row, and has an associated ExperimentData row that defines the compensation parameter.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: References the data set the entity came from

table.name: FlowCytometrySample
table.comment: Defines an experimental sample prepared for use in a flow cytometry experiment. A typical experiment consists of multiple samples X multiple readings (forward/side scatter and using filters of various wavelengths), with a vector of observations (one per cell of the BioSource) for each sample/reading combination.
An ExperimentData row is defined for each observation; see that table for representation details.
An Experiment row is defined to associate each ExperimentData row with the experiment.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse idetification number for this flow cytometry sample

column.name: BioSourceWID
column.comment: References the biological source of this sample.

column.name: FlowCytometryProbeWID
column.comment: References the probe used with this sample.

column.name: MeasurementWID
column.comment: References a specification of the amount of the probe used.

column.name: ManufacturerWID
column.comment: References the Contact that describes the manufacturer of this sample.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: References the data set the entity came from

table.name: FlowCytometryProbe

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse idetification number for this probe

column.name: Type
column.comment: Enumeration. Specifies the type of probe

restriction.description: An acid dye probe
An antibody probe
A protein probe

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

table.name: TranscriptionUnit
table.comment: Defines a transcription unit, similar to an operon. There is a one-to-one relationship between a promoter and a transcription unit. The transcription unit includes the promoter, nearby site that regulate its activity, and downstream genes and the terminator. Unlike operons, a transcription unit can contain a single gene, and a transcription unit can contain only one promoter. For operons containing multiple promoters, a different transcription unit would be created for each operon. See TranscriptionUnitComponent for the types of components represented.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this TranscriptionUnit

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name of the transcription unit

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

table.name: TranscriptionUnitComponent
table.comment: Associates a TranscriptionUnit with its components. Components consist of genes and/or features. A feature component may be either a promoter, a terminator or a DNA binding site (transcription-factor binding site).

column.name: Type
column.comment: Enumeration. Specifies the type of component

column.name: TranscriptionUnitWID
column.comment: Links to the TranscriptionUnit associated with this object.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: WID of the Gene or Feature associated with the TranscriptionUnit

table.name: Chemical
table.comment: Defines small molecular weight chemical compounds.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse idetification number for this chemical

column.name: Name
column.comment: Common name of the chemical

column.name: Class
column.comment: 'T' this is a class or family of related chemicals, else 'F'

column.name: BeilsteinName
column.comment: The Beilstein name of this chemical

column.name: SystematicName
column.comment: The systematic name for this chemical

column.name: CAS
column.comment: The Chemical Abstract Service number

column.name: Charge
column.comment: Charge of the chemical

column.name: EmpiricalFormula
column.comment: The empirical formula of this chemical
Format: { ElementSymbol Integer }+

column.name: MolecularWeightCalc
column.comment: Molecular weight calculated from chemical formula.
Units: Daltons.

column.name: MolecularWeightExp
column.comment: Molecular Weight determined through experimentation. Units: Daltons.

column.name: OctH2OPartitionCoeff
column.comment: Octanol-water-partition coefficient

column.name: PKA1
column.comment: First ionization potential

column.name: PKA2
column.comment: Second ionization potential

column.name: PKA3
column.comment: Third ionization potential

column.name: WaterSolubility
column.comment: 'T' if soluble in water, else 'F'

column.name: Smiles
column.comment: Ascii representation of the chemical structure
Simplified Molecular Input Line Entry System
http://www.epa.gov/medatwrk/databases/smiles.html

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

table.name: Reaction
table.comment: Defines a chemical reaction. The reaction could be enzyme catalyzed
or occur spontaneously. The reaction could involve small molecules, macromolecules,
or a combination of the two. Every reaction will be stored in the warehouse in
a given direction, for example, every reaction that has an assigned EC number is
written in a direction assigned by the enzyme commission. In physiological settings,
the reaction could occur in the direction the reaction is stored, the reverse direction,
or both directions.
Restrictions: Reaction only stores fully qualified EC numbers, e.g., NOT of the form "X.Y.Z.-"

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse ID for this entiry

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name of reaction

column.name: DeltaG
column.comment: Delta G subzero prime value for this reaction

column.name: ECNumber
column.comment: Official enzyme-commission-number.

column.name: ECNumberProposed
column.comment: Proposed enzyme-commission-number

column.name: Spontaneous
column.comment: 'T' if the reaction occurs spontaneously, else 'F'

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: WID of the dataset the reaction is from

table.name: Interaction
table.comment: Defines a molecular interaction, such as two proteins observed to interact in a yeast-two-hybrid experiement. The interaction could involve macromolecules, small molecules or both.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse ID for this interaction

column.name: Type
column.comment: Interaction type. It is recommended to use external controled vacabulary terms, such as PSI-MI Interaction Type CV.

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name of the interaction.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: WID of the dataset the interaction is from.

table.name: Protein
table.comment: Defines a specific protein, that is, a real-world protein which was either purified and isolated,
OR is reasonably inferred by genomic analysis or other means, such as enzymological characterization.
The protein could be a monomer or a multimer. In the latter case, a sequence would not be stored for such a record.

column.name: WID
column.comment: The warehouse ID of this protein

column.name: Name
column.comment: Common name of the protein, if it exists

column.name: AASequence
column.comment: Amino-acid sequence for this protein, if available

column.name: Length
column.comment: Length of the amino-acid sequence for this protein, if available
This value is not necessarily exact, as can be modified by LengthApproximate

column.name: LengthApproximate
column.comment: Indicates that the Length is an approximate. It could be 'gt' for
greater than, 'lt' for less than and 'ne' to indicate that it is not
equal. This is a controlled vocabulary.

column.name: Charge
column.comment: Charge of the chemical

column.name: Fragment
column.comment: 'T' if protein is a fragment, else 'F'

column.name: MolecularWeightCalc
column.comment: Molecular weight calculated from sequence.
Units: kiloDaltons.

column.name: MolecularWeightExp
column.comment: Molecular Weight determined through experimentation.
Units: kiloDaltons.

column.name: PICalc
column.comment: Isoelectric point (pI) calculated from its sequence.

column.name: PIExp
column.comment: Isoelectric point (pI) determined through experimentation.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: WID of the dataset the protein is from

table.name: Feature
table.comment: Features define regions or points of interest on the protein sequence or
nucleic acid sequence specified by SequenceWID.
Features are not used to describe objects such as Genes, BioSources, etc,
because attributes of those objects are described in their own tables.
Exceptions:
1. Since pseudogenes are not entered in the Gene table, they are listed as sequence features in Feature

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier of this feature.

column.name: Description
column.comment: Textual description of this feature.

column.name: Type
column.comment: Type of feature. These type values come from the source dataset and
are not necessarily enumerated. Example: "Promoter CYZ".

column.name: Class
column.comment: Class of feature. Assigns our typology for types of features, or qualifiers
associated with features. These are our own enumerated type values, to allow us
to classify features without losing the original (author-provided) type values
stored in Type. Example: Class=promoter.

restriction.description: Identifies the presence of a DNA binding site
Identifies the presence of a promoter
Identifies the presence of a terminator
Identifies a pseudogene, whether non-transcribed or processed
Identifies a truly unknown open reading frame according to warehouse definition (no strong evidence that a product is produced)
Qualifier: States that feature is not complete
Identifies an unspecified product is produced from this genomic location, as stated in dataset
Qualifier: Characterizes the feature value as notable (same as 'Exceptional' in GB dataset)
Qualifier: states that feature was derived by similarity analysis
Qualifier: states that feature may be incorrect
Qualifier: states that feature is probably correct

column.name: SequenceType
column.comment: Enumeration (see also SequenceWID) that indicates whether the sequence
is protein or nucleic and how the sequence (if available) is represented:
If 'P', feature resides on a protein.
If 'S' or 'N', feature resides on a nucleic acid.

restriction.description: Feature resides on a protein. Implies SequenceWID (if nonNULL) references a Protein
Feature resides on a nucleic acid. Implies SequenceWID is nonNULL and references a Subsequence
Feature resides on a nucleic acid. Implies SequenceWID (if nonNULL) references a NucleicAcid

column.name: SequenceWID
column.comment: References the Protein or Subsequence containing the sequence on which we
are defining a feature:
SequenceType of 'S' implies SequenceWID is nonNULL and references a Subsequence-
sequence = Subsequence.Sequence (i.e., it is stored explicitly),
SequenceType of 'N' implies SequenceWID (if nonNULL) references a NucleicAcid-
sequence is the substring Subsequence.Sequence[StartPosition : EndPosition]
where Subsequence is the full Subsequence of the nucleic acid.
SequenceType of 'P' implies SequenceWID (if nonNULL) references a Protein-
sequence is the substring Protein.AASequence[StartPosition : EndPosition].

column.name: Variant
column.comment: Amino-acid sequence for this protein, if available

column.name: RegionOrPoint
column.comment: Specifies whether this feature is specified with starting and ending coordinates
or with a single coordinate.

restriction.description: Feature is specified by a start point and an end point on the sequence
Feature is specified by a single point on the sequence

column.name: PointType
column.comment: Only defined if RegionOrPoint='point'. Specifies where the feature is relative
to its location as encoded in StartPosition and EndPosition:

restriction.description: Feature is centered at location.
Feature extends to the left (decreasing position) of location.
Feature extends to the right (increasing position) of location.

column.name: StartPosition
column.comment: Start position of the feature within the NucleicAcid or Protein sequence.
If Feature.RegionOrPoint is 'point', StartPosition and EndPosition will
either be equal (location is exactly at a nucleotide or amino acid) or will differ by 1
(location is centered between two adjacent nucleotides or amino acids).

column.name: EndPosition
column.comment: End position of the feature within the NucleicAcid or Protein sequence.
If Feature.RegionOrPoint is 'point', StartPosition and EndPosition will
either be equal (location is exactly at a nucleotide or amino acid) or will differ by 1
(location is between two adjacent nucleotides or amino acids).

column.name: StartPositionApproximate
column.comment: Indicates that the Start position of the coding region is an approximate value
It could be 'gt' for greater than, 'lt' for less than and 'ne' to indicate that it is not
equal. This is a controlled vocabulary.

restriction.description: The start position of the feature is greater than the actual position specified.
The start position of the feature is less than the actual position specified.
The start position of the feature is less than or greater than the actual position. All we know is that its not the exact position.

column.name: EndPositionApproximate
column.comment: Indicates that the End position of the coding region is an approximate value.
It could be 'gt' for greater than, 'lt' for less than and 'ne' to indicate that it is not
equal. This is a controlled vocabulary.

restriction.description: The end position of the feature is greater than the actual position specified.
The end position of the feature is less than the actual position specified.
The end position of the feature is less than or greater than the actual position. All we know is that its not the exact position.

column.name: ExperimentalSupport
column.comment: 'T' if the feature is supported by experimental evidence, else 'F'

column.name: ComputationalSupport
column.comment: 'T' if the feature is supported by computational evidence, else 'F'

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

table.name: Function
table.comment: Describes the non-enzymatic function(s) of proteins. That is,
this table should not be used to describe the enzymatic function of a protein whose enzymatic
function is described using the EnzymaticReaction table. Function names are stored as
strings with no particular format or interpretation.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this function.

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name of this function.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Data set the entity came from

table.name: EnzymaticReaction
table.comment: Defines an association between a reaction and an enzyme that catalyzes
that reaction (ProteinWID). In the case where we are defining an
association between a subunit of a larger enzyme complex, and a
reaction catalyzed by that subunit only when the subunit is part of
that larger complex, ComplexWID specifies that larger complex (assumes
that complex is in the warehouse).
This table requires a WID as it is referenced in multiple linking tables
to associate alternate compounds, cofactors, etc., to allow for multiple
valued attributes of the enzymatic reaction.

column.name: WID
column.comment: WID of this enzymatic reaction

column.name: ReactionWID
column.comment: WID of the catalyzed reaction

column.name: ProteinWID
column.comment: WID of the enzyme

column.name: ComplexWID
column.comment: WID of protein of which ProteinWID
must be a subunit of for this reaction

column.name: ReactionDirection
column.comment: Reaction Direction Enumeration

restriction.description: Reaction occurs in both directions in physiological settings.
Reaction occurs in the left-to-right direction in physiological settings.
Reaction occurs in the right-to-left direction in physiological settings.
For all practical purposes, the reaction occurs only in the left-to-right direction in physiological settings, because of chemical properties of the reaction.
For all practical purposes, the reaction occurs only in the right-to-left direction in physiological settings, because of chemical properties of the reaction.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: WID of the dataset the reaction is from

table.name: GeneticCode
table.comment: Defines the genetic codes with a name, translation table and a start codon for each code.
See http://embryology.med.unsw.edu.au/DNA/Genetic_Codes.htm for more information.
Genbank ID is stored as DBID.XID, where DBID.OtherWID = GeneticCode.WID.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse ID for this GeneticCode.

column.name: NCBIID
column.comment: 1- or 2-digit ID assigned to this code. See URL above.

column.name: Name
column.comment: Genetic code name.

column.name: TranslationTable
column.comment: Translation table for this genetic code. See URL above for format.

column.name: StartCodon
column.comment: Start Codon for this genetic code. See URL above for format

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from.

table.name: Division
table.comment: Stores the GenBank Division and the NCBI three letter code for records originating from GenBank. NCBI uses Divisions to organize GenBank records according to two definitions: some divisions are based on taxonomy (e.g., the "BCT" division), whereas other divisions exist purely for data organization reasons (e.g., the "CON" division, whose records store instructions for the construction of large contigs). Sequences from different GenBank divisions vary substantially in quality based upon the way they were generated, e.g., single-pass genomic sequencing, ESTs (low quality, single-pass sequencing), cDNAs (high coverage sequencing) and genomic sequencing (moderate coverage sequencing). All BioWarehouse records associated with a GenBank dataset also have a record in the Division table.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse ID for this Division.

column.name: Code
column.comment: Genbank Division code (3 characters) which is an abbreviation for the GenBank Name.

column.name: Name
column.comment: Division name.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from.

table.name: Taxon
table.comment: Defines a taxon, which could be a species, genus, family or some other rank.
These ranks are controlled vocabulary and are stored in the Enumeration table.
The taxon table associates a taxon with its parent, gives the name, division code and the
genetic code information for the taxon.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse ID for this Taxon

column.name: ParentWID
column.comment: Warehouse ID of the parent of this taxon

column.name: Name
column.comment: Taxonomic Name of this taxon

column.name: Rank
column.comment: Rank of this taxon (kingdom, superkingdom ..)

Origin:NCBI- Taxonomy database. Parent:superkingdom
Origin:NCBI- Taxonomy database. Parent: root
Origin:NCBI- Taxonomy database

column.name: DivisionWID
column.comment: Warehouse ID of the division this taxon belongs to.

column.name: InheritedDivision
column.comment: 'T' if division is inherited from parent, else 'F'

column.name: GencodeWID
column.comment: Warehouse ID of the genetic code for this taxon.

column.name: InheritedGencode
column.comment: 'T' if gencode is inherited from parent, else 'F'

column.name: MCGencodeWID
column.comment: Warehouse ID of the mitochondrial genetic code for this taxon.

column.name: InheritedMCGencode
column.comment: 'T' if the mitochondrial gencode is inherited from parent, else 'F'

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

table.name: BioSource
table.comment: Defines the biological source of an entry in the Protein, NucleicAcid or Gene tables ("the object"), as well as other tables eventually storing experimental data related to e.g., microarray or proteomic experiments. For example, BioSource might be used to specify the organism, organ, and tissue in which gene expression experiments were performed. DEPENDENCIES: 1. As BioSource references Taxon.WID to specify the species, the NCBI taxonomy dataset must have ALREADY been loaded prior to populating BioSource. 2. BioSource stores subtype information in BioSubtype via the BioSourceWIDBioSubtypeWID linking table

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for biological source.

column.name: MAGEClass
column.comment: Discriminator column specifies type of MAGE object this row represents (if needed)

column.name: TaxonWID
column.comment: Warehouse GUID identifying WID of Taxon entry for the species. Always references species level or higher.

column.name: Name
column.comment: Informal name assigned to this source.
Ex. (CMR): 'Escherichia coli K12-MG1655'

column.name: Strain
column.comment: Strain of organism from which object is derived, if applicable. This is a subspecies taxonomic classification not supported by Taxon because it is not a rigorous concept. Strain is defined as a population of homogeneous organisms possessing a set of defined characteristics. In bacteriology, the set of descendants that retains the characteristics of the ancestor. Members of a strain that subsequently differ from the original isolate are regarded as belonging either to a substrain of the original strain, or to a new strain.

column.name: Organ
column.comment: Organ of organism from which object is derived, if applicable.
Organ is defined as any part of the body exercising a specific function, such as
respiration, secretion, or digestion, if applicable.

column.name: Organelle
column.comment: Organelle of organism from which object is derived, if applicable.

column.name: Tissue
column.comment: Tissue of organism from which object is derived, if applicable. Can be used in
conjunction with Organ.
Tissue is defined as a collection of similar cells and the intercellular substances
surrounding them. Multiple tissues can be part of an Organ.

column.name: CellType
column.comment: Cell type of organism from which object is derived, if applicable.
Cell type is defined as the type of an individual cell, e.g., "myoblast". This is a
cellular-level classification.

column.name: CellLine
column.comment: Cell line from which object is derived, if applicable
Cell line usually pertains to an immortalized version of a given cell type

column.name: ATCCId
column.comment: Identifier assigned by ATCC.org to the cell.

column.name: Diseased
column.comment: 'T' if source is diseased, else 'F'.

column.name: Disease
column.comment: If source was diseased, describes the disease borne by it.

column.name: DevelopmentStage
column.comment: Stage of development associated with the object, if applicable

column.name: Sex
column.comment: Sex of the organism from which object is derived, if applicable Enumerated. Values=Male/Female/Hermaphrodite/Asexual/NULL (NULL here means not provided by dataset)

restriction.description: Sex of organism is male
Sex of organism is female
Sex of organism is hermaphrodite
The notion of a sex does not apply to this organism

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: The dataset this entity came from or is associated with

table.name: BioSubtype
table.comment: Describes idiosyncratic sub-species descriptions such as "serotype", "variety", etc.
These can be many to one (1 BioSource - many BioSubtypes) linked via BioSourceWIDBioSubtypeWID

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse GUID for this BioSubtype

column.name: Type
column.comment: Type of subtype, e.g., "serotype"

column.name: Value
column.comment: Value of the subtype, e.g., "O157"

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: The dataset this entity came from or is associated with

table.name: NucleicAcid
table.comment: Defines a specific nucleic acid molecule, such as DNA or of RNA.
Entries in this table correspond to a real-world DNA or RNA molecules
which at one point were purified and isolated ("something you can point at"). A row in this table
can define a complete molecule, a fragment of a molecule, or a molecule that has been partially
sequenced in different regions.
This table will be used in several ways: (1) to associate a sequence with an entire
replicon, or a region of a replicon, when the sequence of that replicon is known; (2) to associate
a DNA sequence with a single gene; (3) to define a DNA or RNA molecule that has not been
sequenced; (4) to define RNA molecules such as tRNAs.
Features on a NucleicAcid molecule (such as promoters or binding sites) can be defined using
the Feature table.
The Subsequence table contains zero or more full or partial sequences contents of this molecule.
If one represents the full sequence of this molecule, Subsequence.FullSequence = 'T' where
Subsequence.NucleicAcidWID references this molecule. In this case, NucleicAcid.FullySequenced = 'T' as well.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this NucleicAcid.

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name or description of this molecule.
Ex: (CMR) 'Chromosome II Brucella melitensis 16M'.

column.name: Type
column.comment: Enumeration: 'DNA' 'RNA' or 'na'

restriction.description: The molecule is composed of DNA
The molecule is composed of RNA
The molecule is specified as a nucleic acid but whether of type DNA or RNA is not known

column.name: Class
column.comment: Enumeration: describes the molecule as it exists in the organism; stores values such as RNA subtype ("pre-RNA", "mRNA"), replicon type (e.g., "chromosome", "plasmid")

restriction.description: As it exists within the organism, the molecule is a pre-RNA molecule. NCBI: used when there is no evidence that mature RNA is produced
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is a mature mRNA. NCBI: used when there is evidence that mature mRNA is produced
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is an rRNA; NCBI used when there is evidence that mature rRNA is produced
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is a tRNA; NCBI: used when there is evidence that mature tRNA is produced
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is a small nuclear RNA. NCBI: used when there is evidence that snRNA is produced

As it exists within the organism, the molecule is an RNA which encodes small cytoplasmic ribonucleic proteins. NCBI: used when there is evidence that gene codes of small cytoplasmic (sc) ribonucleoproteins (RNP)s
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is a small nucleolar RNA. NCBI: used when there is evidence that transcript is a small nucleolar RNA
Check notes as to how we map this...
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is a chromosome
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is a plasmid
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is the chromosome of an organelle
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is a transposon
As it exists within the organism, the molecule is a virus
Used when the class is unknown

column.name: Topology
column.comment: Enumeration: 'circular', 'linear' or 'other'.

restriction.description: The topology of the molecule is Linear
The topology of the molecule is Circular
The topology of the molecule is neither circular nor linear but is known

column.name: Strandedness
column.comment: Enumeration indicating whether Nucleic Acid is single stranded, double stranded or mixed stranded.

restriction.description: The molecule is single stranded
The molecule is double stranded
The molecule is composed of single and double stranded regions

column.name: SequenceDerivation
column.comment: Enumeration describing how the sequence was generated
(e.g., from single clone, from assembly of sequences
from other sequence entries, collection of different clones, etc).

restriction.description: NCBI: The sequence of the molecule is NOT known. NOTE: this should map to null.

POORLY DEFINED; seems to be used to indicate that the sequence of the molecule was actually generated from one single continuous molecule, as opposed to assembled together from sequences from different molecules (e.g., different clones)
NCBI: The sequence of the molecule is made up of collection of segments arranged according to specified coordinates, e.g., sequence was derived from assembling sequences from different clones
NCBI: The sequence of the molecule is constructed from existing Bioseqs;It behaves exactly like a segmented Bioseq in taking it's data and character from the Bioseq to which it points.
NCBI: The sequence of the molecule is constructed by assembling other Bioseqs

NCBI: The sequence of the molecule represents a pattern typical of a sequence region or family of sequences;' it summarizes attributes of an aligned collection of real sequences. Note that this is NOT A REAL OBJECT
NCBI: The molecule does not have a sequence describing it, but rather a set of coordinates (restriction fragment order, genetic markers, physical map, etc)

column.name: Fragment
column.comment: 'T' if this is a fragment of a molecule,
'F' if this NucleicAcid describes an entire molecule.

column.name: FullySequenced
column.comment: 'T' if the molecule is completely
sequenced within this dataset, else 'F'.

column.name: MoleculeLength
column.comment: The length of the molecule, in nucleotides. This value is firm if FullySequenced is 'T';
otherwise,MoleculeLength is an approximation and is not necessarily equal to CumulativeLength,
as the the molecule may not have been sequenced to completion.
This value is calculated if it is not explicitely stated in the source dataset

column.name: MoleculeLengthApproximate
column.comment: Enumeration; specifies whether MoleculeLength stores an approximate value:
'gt' for greater than,
'lt' for less than, or
'ne' for not equal.

restriction.description: The length of the molecule's sequence is greater than the actual length specified
The length of the molecule's sequence is less than the actual length specified
The length of the molecule's sequence is less than or greater than the actual length. All we know is that its not the exact length

column.name: CumulativeLength
column.comment: The cumulative number of nucleotides for all Subsequences referenced by this NucleicAcid entry,
whether contiguous or not. This value is a summation of the number of nucleotides for these Subsequences.
If the molecule is completely sequenced, this value should be identical
to that of MoleculeLength, and both fields are populated.

column.name: CumulativeLengthApproximate
column.comment: Enumeration; specifies whether CumulativeLength how approximates actual total length:
'gt' for greater than,
'lt' for less than, or
'ne' for not equal.

restriction.description: The total length of the molecule's sequence is greater than the actual length
The total length of the molecule's sequence is less than the actual length
The total length of the molecule's sequence is less than or greater than the actual length. All we know is that its not the exact length

column.name: GeneticCodeWID
column.comment: References the genetic code of this molecule.

column.name: BioSourceWID
column.comment: References the biological source of this molecule.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: References the data set from which the entity came from

table.name: Subsequence
table.comment: Contains a contiguous sequence of a nucleic acid molecule. Multiple Subsequences can make up a given NucleicAcid entry.
Contains either the full or partial nucleotide sequence of the nucleic acid molecule stored in NucleicAcid.
Todo: Currently the schema has no way of indicating an approximate position
of this Subsequence on the NucleicAcid as a whole.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this Subsequence.

column.name: NucleicAcidWID
column.comment: References the containing nucleic acid molecule.

column.name: FullSequence
column.comment: 'T' if this is the complete sequence of the nucleic acid molecule
referenced by NucleicAcidWID, else 'F'.

column.name: Sequence
column.comment: Nucleotide sequence of this Subsequence.

column.name: Length
column.comment: Number of nucleotides (and characters) in Sequence. This value
is calculated if it is not explicitely stated in the source
dataset

column.name: LengthApproximate
column.comment: Enumeration; indicates that Length approximates actual Sequence length:
'gt' for greater than,
'lt' for less than, or
'ne' for not equal.

column.name: PercentGC
column.comment: Percentage of Sequence nucleotides that are either guanine or cytosine.
This value is calculated if it is not explicitely stated in the source
dataset

column.name: Version
column.comment: Dataset-specific information to indicate the version of this Subsequence.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

table.name: Gene
table.comment: Defines a notion of gene that is limited to procaryotic aspects of
genes. Later versions of the warehouse will expand this definition to include
eukaryotic aspects of genes. Separate tables define associations between a gene and
(1) its biological source(s),
(2) its protein product(s), if any, and
(3) its RNA product(s), if any.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier this gene.

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name of the gene.

column.name: NucleicAcidWID
column.comment: Reference to the NucleicAcid molecule (replicon) this gene resides upon.

column.name: SubsequenceWID
column.comment: Reference to the Subsequence containing the nucleotide sequence of this Gene.

column.name: Type
column.comment: Describes the type of molecule which is known to be *ultimately* produced by this gene
enumerated values (polypeptide, pre-mRNA, rRNA, tRNA, etc)

restriction.description: used when transcriptional status of gene is unknown
used when there is no evidence that a mature RNA is ultimately produced by the gene
used when there is evidence that a mature mRNA is ultimately produced by the gene
used when there is evidence that a mature rRNA is ultimately produced by the gene
used when there is evidence that a mature tRNA is ultimately produced by the gene
used when there is evidence that an snRNA is ultimately produced by the gene
used when there is evidence that the ultimate product of this gene is proteinaceous
catchall ?

column.name: GenomeID
column.comment: Unique ID assigned to this gene, such as by a genome project

column.name: CodingRegionStart
column.comment: Base position of start of coding region. Start is always less than End,
except for genes that wrap around the origin of a circular chromosome.

column.name: CodingRegionEnd
column.comment: Base position of end of coding region.
Indexes the stop codon that terminates the gene.

column.name: CodingRegionStartApproximate
column.comment: Indicates that the Start position of the coding region is an approximate value.
It could be 'gt' for greater than, 'lt' for less than and 'ne' to indicate that it is not
equal. This is a controlled vocabulary.

column.name: CodingRegionEndApproximate
column.comment: Indicates that the End position of the coding region is an approximate value.
It could be 'gt' for greater than, 'lt' for less than and 'ne' to indicate that it is not
equal. This is a controlled vocabulary.

column.name: Direction
column.comment: Direction of transcription as defined in the enumeration table

restriction.description: unknown the strand being transcribed is unknown
the plus strand is being transcribed
the minus strand is being transcribed
both strands are being transcribed
UNDEFINED; the NCBI documentation does not define this value

column.name: Interrupted
column.comment: 'T' if the gene is interrupted, else 'F'.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

table.name: Pathway
table.comment: Pathways are graphs of reactions, grouped together according to a
higher biological function they perform. Some pathways may be
"template", "reference", "model" or "sum of organisms" pathways. Those
pathways do not contain an BioSourceWID reference, and have the type
field set to "R" (Reference/Model/Theoretical). For real organisms,
the type is "O".

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse ID for this pathway

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name of the pathway

restriction.description: Name assigned when it is unknown or missing

column.name: Type
column.comment: Type of pathway (see comment above)

column.name: BioSourceWID
column.comment: BioSource this pathway occurs in

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: WID of the dataset the pathway is from

table.name: Term
table.comment: A term is a controlled vocabulary term used within a particular dataset.
E.g. the keyword attached to proteins in SwissProt. Terms can be arranged
in a hierarchy (see the TermRelationship table).

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this term

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name for the term

column.name: Definition
column.comment: Definition of the term

column.name: Hierarchical
column.comment: 'T' if term is part of a hierarchy of terms

column.name: Root
column.comment: 'T' if this term is at the top of a hierarchy

column.name: Obsolete
column.comment: 'T' if term is known to be obsolete

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: WID of the dataset the pathway is from

table.name: Computation
table.comment: Defines a parameterized computation that has been performed on objects in the warehouse.
TODO: Parameters are specified in the Parameter table.

column.name: WID
column.comment: WID of this computation

column.name: Name
column.comment: Name of the algorithm, procedure, or program, e.g. 'BLAST'

column.name: Description
column.comment: Description of the computation performed

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: WID of the dataset the computation is from

table.name: Citation
table.comment: Defines a literature citation.
Typically a citation is associated with one or more Warehouse objects via the CitationWIDOtherWID table.

column.name: WID
column.comment: WID of this citation

column.name: Citation
column.comment: Line of text containing the citation

column.name: PMID
column.comment: Pubmed ID of the citation, if known

column.name: Title

column.name: Authors
column.comment: Author name(s)

column.name: Publication

column.name: Publisher

column.name: Editor

column.name: Year

column.name: Volume
column.comment: Volume of publication

column.name: Issue
column.comment: Issue number

column.name: Pages

column.name: URI
column.comment: Publication URI

column.name: DataSetWID
