table.name: Archive
table.comment: Defines an association between a warehouse entity and an external representation or depiction
of that entity in a well-defined format.
Can be used to store the contents itself, or to indicate that an archive is present at a URL.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entity

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: WID of entity archive is associated with

column.name: Format
column.comment: Storage/compression format used eg. 'zip' 'tar' 'tgz' 'jpeg'

column.name: Contents
column.comment: Archive contents

column.name: URL
column.comment: Web address the archive is found at, ideally a specific file

column.name: ToolName
column.comment: The name of the tool or software kit the archive is used by
eg. 'MIAMExpress'

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: DataSet.WID this entity is associated with

table.name: Experiment
table.comment: Defines an experiment. Provides a context for associating experimental data with it.
Allows tree-structured experiments consisting of heterogeneous subexperiments,
subexperiments corresponding to time-series observations,
and repeated trials of identical experiments.
For a hierarchical experiment, data should be associated with the Experiment
at the appropriate level. For example, if data reflects results from averaging
numerous identically conducted trials, that data should be associated with the
Experiment representing the group of these trials.
A Comment table entry may be created to contain discussion of results, etc.
A DBID table entry may be created if the (sub)experiment has a unique name within its DataSet.
SynonymTable table entries may be created to associate names with the (sub)experiment.
If published, a reference may be created in Citation table.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entity

column.name: Type
column.comment: Mnemonic for the general type of experiment, e.g. 'microarray'

column.name: ContactWID
column.comment: Contact.WID for submitter/investigator

column.name: ArchiveWID
column.comment: Archive.WID of external rep'n of experiment and its data.

column.name: StartDate
column.comment: Date+time experiment was started

column.name: EndDate
column.comment: Date+time experiment was completed

column.name: Description
column.comment: Description of this experiment

column.name: GroupWID
column.comment: Experiment.WID defining the parent group of this subexperiment

column.name: GroupType
column.comment: Enumeration indicating type of any and all direct subexperiments
Exs: 'replicate' 'variant' 'step' 'time-series'

restriction.description: All subexperiments attempt to replicate identical experimental conditions and parameters
Subexperiments are variations upon an experimental procedure, technique, conditions, and/or parameters
Subexperiments consist of observations according to a specific schedule
Subexperiments comprise an experimental procedure and consist of an ordered sequence

column.name: GroupSize
column.comment: Number of child experiments loaded

column.name: GroupIndex
column.comment: Counter value identifying this experiment in a sequence or set
of subexperiments (eg. time-series). NULL if GroupWID is NULL.

column.name: TimePoint
column.comment: Time offset indicating when associated observations in a
time-series experiment were conducted

column.name: TimeUnit
column.comment: Enumeration for units of TimePoint

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: DataSet.WID this entity is associated with

column.name: BioSourceWID
column.comment: References the biological source of this experiment, if applicable.

table.name: ExperimentData
table.comment: Specifies a relationship between one data entity and an experiment in which it was recorded as an observation or used in some other fashion.
Used in flow cytometry to represent both observations and filter wavelengths.
For an observation:
ExperimentData.Data contains the vector of observations
ExperimentData.MageData = NULL
ExperimentData.OtherWID = the FlowCytometrySample.WID of the sample,
ExperimentData.Role defines the reading ('forward scatter', 'side scatter', or 'filter'),
ExperimentData.Type = 'flow cytometry',
ExperimentData.Kind = 'O' (observation)
For a filter wavelength:
ExperimentData.Data = NULL
ExperimentData.MageData references a ParameterValue row for the wavelength
ExperimentData.Role = 'filter wavelength'
ExperimentData.Kind = 'P' (parameter)
ExperimentData.OtherWID = the ExperimentData.WID of the observation,

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entity

column.name: ExperimentWID
column.comment: Experiment entity

column.name: Data
column.comment: Data associated with experiment, in an unspecified format. May be specified instead of or along with MageData.

column.name: MageData
column.comment: Data associated with experiment using MAGE structure. May be specified instead of or along with Data.

column.name: Role
column.comment: Describes how data is used in experiment
ex: 'green intensity', 'forward scatter', 'filter wavelength'

column.name: Kind
column.comment: Characterizes relationship of data to experiment

restriction.description: Data is an observation
Data is computed from an observation
Data is a parameter to a procedure or compuatation
Data is metadata describing other data

column.name: DateProduced
column.comment: When the observation was taken, the computation was performed, etc.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: WID of entity this experiment data is associated with. If Kind='O', it is typically the sample or specimen being observed. If Kind='P', it is typically another ExperimentData or ParameterizableApplication that is parameterized by this entity.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: The data set this entity came from or is associated with

table.name: Support
table.comment: Describes the source and strength of evidence for individual facts in the warehouse.
This table is designed to allow different types of evidential support to be asserted for
different types of database assertions, such as using one set of evidence types for supporting
assertions about protein function, and another, possibly overlapping set of evidence types
for supporting assertions about protein existence.
Example use: Record that there are two sources of support for the function of a given
protein, one computational and one experimental. This table has a WID for use in the
CitationWIDOtherWID table.

column.name: WID
column.comment: WID of this support

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: WID of supported entity, e.g. Protein Function

column.name: Type
column.comment: Type: Identifies the type of assertion that this row pertains to.

restriction.description: The evidence supports protein function
The evidence supports protein existence

column.name: EvidenceType
column.comment: EvidenceType: Defines the type of evidential support that this row pertains to.

restriction.description: Valid when type is 'protein function'. Protein function is supported by a computational prediction (example: existence of a gene could be supported by a gene-finding program).

Valid when type is 'protein function'. Protein function is supported by data from a wet-lab experiment (example: existence of a gene could be supported observation of the gene's mRNA product in a microarray experiment).
Valid when type is 'protein existence'. Protein existence is supported by the evidences at protein level (e.g. clear identification by mass spectrometry).
Valid when type is 'protein existence'. Protein existence is supported by evidences at transcript level (e.g. Northern blot).
Valid when type is 'protein existence'. Protein existence is inferred by homology (strong sequence similarity to known proteins in related species).
Valid when type is 'protein existence'. Protein existence is predicted
Valid when type is 'protein existence'. Protein existence is uncertain (e.g. dubious sequences that could be the erroneous translation of a pseudogene).

column.name: Confidence
column.comment: 0 < confidence <= 1.

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: The data set this entity came from or is associated with

table.name: ChemicalAtom
table.comment: The tables ChemicalAtom and ChemicalBond define the chemical bond structure of a chemical, the
charge on the constituent atoms, and encodes a two or three dimensional representation of the
structure. It is implicit that ChemicalBonds are symmetric.
Atoms that are chiral centers are have a non-zero StereoParity field. Values for this field are
defined in the Enumeration table, and are taken from MDL Molfile format defined in
http://www.mdli.com/downloads/ctfile/ctfile_subs.html . That specification is confusing because
it appears to define two redundant ways (marking atoms and marking bonds) of defining stereo
configurations. Our theory is that the redundancy exists to allow different drawings of stereo
configurations, and that for simply capturing a configuration, setting the StereoParity field
of an atom is sufficient. Also, setting the BondStereo field of a bond could simplify drawing
of chemical structures, and can allow different drawings of the same stereo configurations,
which can be desirable. But these two fields can be interpreted independently of one another.
See the appendix of the MDL specification for details on interpreting stereo configurations.
E.g. H2O could be encoded as:
ChemicalAtom (wid, 1, 'H', 0)
ChemicalAtom (wid, 2, 'O', 0)
ChemicalAtom (wid, 3, 'H', 0)
ChemicalBond (wid, 1, 2, 1)
ChemicalBond (wid, 2, 3, 1)

column.name: ChemicalWID
column.comment: WID of the chemical

column.name: AtomIndex
column.comment: Order of the atoms within the structure,
starting from 1

column.name: Atom
column.comment: Element symbol of the atom

column.name: Charge
column.comment: Charge on the atom

column.name: X
column.comment: X display coordinates for a drawing of the chemical structure

column.name: Y
column.comment: Y display coordinates for a drawing of the chemical structure

column.name: Z
column.comment: Z display coordinates for a drawing of the chemical structure

column.name: StereoParity
column.comment: Defines parity of an atom that is a chiral center.

restriction.description: Not stereo.
Odd parity.
Even parity.
Either or unmarked stereo center.

table.name: ChemicalBond
table.comment: The tables ChemicalAtom and ChemicalBond define the chemical bond structure of a chemical, the charge on
the constituent atoms, and encodes a two or three dimensional representation of the structure.
It is implicit that ChemicalBonds are symmetric. BondTypes and BondStereo are defined in the
Enumeration table, and are taken from MDL Molfile format defined in
http://www.mdli.com/downloads/ctfile/ctfile_subs.html . That specification is confusing. See
documentation of ChemicalAtom table for more information.
E.g. H2O could be encoded as:
ChemicalAtom (wid, 1, 'H', 0)
ChemicalAtom (wid, 2, 'O', 0)
ChemicalAtom (wid, 3, 'H', 0)
ChemicalBond (wid, 1, 2, 1)
ChemicalBond (wid, 2, 3, 1)

column.name: ChemicalWID
column.comment: WID of the chemical

column.name: Atom1Index
column.comment: Index of first atom bonded (from ChemicalAtom)

column.name: Atom2Index
column.comment: Index of second atom bonded

column.name: BondType
column.comment: Type of bond enumeration, e.g., 1=Single, 2=Double, 3=Triple, 4=Aromatic.

restriction.description: Single bond.
Double bond.
Triple bond.
Aromatic bond.
Single or double bond.
Single or aromatic bond.
Double or aromatic bond.
Any bond.

column.name: BondStereo
column.comment: Stereo information about bond, e.g., 0 = Not stereo.

restriction.description: For single bonds, 0 = not stereo. Four double bonds, 0 = use X,Y,Z coords to determine cis or trans.
For single bonds, 1 = up.
For double bonds, 3 = cis or trans (either) (presumably meaning unspecified or a mixture).
For single bonds, 4 = either.
For single bonds, 6 = down.

table.name: EnzReactionCofactor
table.comment: Cofactors are chemicals that are required for the enzyme to catalyze
the reaction, but are left unchanged by the reaction. If multiple
cofactors are listed for a reaction, this is interpreted as a disjunction.
This table also encodes prosthetic groups.

column.name: EnzymaticReactionWID
column.comment: EnzymaticReaction.WID of the Enzymatic Reaction

column.name: ChemicalWID
column.comment: Chemical.WID of the compound

column.name: Prosthetic
column.comment: 'T' if covalently/tightly bound to enzyme, else 'F'

table.name: EnzReactionAltCompound
table.comment: Identifies a compound that is either an alternate substrate or an alternate cofactor
to a primary compound present in an enzymatic reaction.

column.name: EnzymaticReactionWID
column.comment: EnzymaticReaction.WID of the Enzymatic Reaction

column.name: PrimaryWID
column.comment: Chemical.WID of primary compound

column.name: AlternativeWID
column.comment: Chemical.WID of alternate compound

column.name: Cofactor
column.comment: 'T' if this alternative is a cofactor, 'F' if it is a substrate

table.name: EnzReactionInhibitorActivator
table.comment: Associates an enzymatic reaction to the compounds that act as
inhibitors and activators for the reaction.
The mechanism of action is encoded in the Mechanism column.

column.name: EnzymaticReactionWID
column.comment: EnzymaticReaction.WID of the Enzymatic Reaction

column.name: CompoundWID
column.comment: Chemical.WID or Protein.WID of the compound

column.name: InhibitOrActivate
column.comment: Specifies whether the compound is an inhibitor or an activator.

restriction.description: Specifies a compound that inhibits an enzyme.
Specifies a compound that activates an enzyme.

column.name: Mechanism
column.comment: Mechanism of inhibition or activation.

restriction.description: The mechanism of inhibition or activation is allosteric.
The mechanism of inhibition or activation is irreversible.
The mechanism of inhibition or activation is competitive.
The mechanism of inhibition or activation is neither allosteric nor competitive.
The mechanism of inhibition or activation is known but not in this controlled vocabulary.
The mechanism of inhibition or activation is unknown.

column.name: PhysioRelevant
column.comment: 'T' if physiologically relevant, else 'F'

table.name: Location
table.comment: Defines one or more locations of a protein.

column.name: ProteinWID
column.comment: WID of the protein

column.name: Location
column.comment: Subcellular location of a protein.

table.name: PathwayLink
table.comment: This table allows us to state that two pathways are neighbors in
a biologically significant sense, because they share a substrate
in common. This link between two pathways is represented by the WIDs of the
interacting pathways, and of the chemical compound that they share.

column.name: Pathway1WID
column.comment: WID of one of the linked pathways

column.name: Pathway2WID
column.comment: WID of the other linked pathways

column.name: ChemicalWID
column.comment: WID of the linking chemical

table.name: PathwayReaction
table.comment: A pathway is defined as a set of reaction pairs or a collection of molecular interactions between molecules. This table stores not only the relationships between pathway and reactions, but also relationships between molecular interaction network/pathway and interactions. For each pair of reactions R1 and R2, R1 directly precedes R2 in the pathway. Some reactions in a pathway may be considered hypothetical, probably because the presence of the enzyme has not been demonstrated. To specify an interaction is a part of a molecular interaction network/pathway, use R2 to represents a molecular interaction, leave R1 blank.

column.name: PathwayWID
column.comment: WID of a pathway

column.name: ReactionWID
column.comment: WID of a reaction, R2, in the pathway

column.name: PriorReactionWID
column.comment: WID, R1, of a predecessor reaction of R2

column.name: Hypothetical
column.comment: 'F' if R2 proven to exist, 'T' otherwise.

table.name: Product
table.comment: Associates a reaction with a chemical product of that reaction.

column.name: ReactionWID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier of the reaction that this reactant is part of.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: Reference to the chemical or protein that is the reactant.

column.name: Coefficient
column.comment: The number of molecules of this reactant used in the reaction.

table.name: Reactant
table.comment: Associates a reaction with a chemical that is consumed by the reaction.

column.name: ReactionWID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier of the reaction that this reactant is part of

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: Reference to the chemical or protein that is the reactant.

column.name: Coefficient
column.comment: The amount of this reactant used in the reation

table.name: InteractionParticipant
table.comment: Associates an interaction with the entity that participates in the interaction.

column.name: InteractionWID
column.comment: Reference to the interaction that the entity is involved in.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: Reference to the protein, nucletic acid, chemical that involves in the interaction.

column.name: Coefficient
column.comment: The amount of this interaction participant involved in the interaction, if available.

table.name: SequenceMatch
table.comment: Records a result of a computation of the degree of match between two sequences.
Sequences are either both Proteins or both Subsequences.

column.name: QueryWID
column.comment: WID of the Protein or Subsequence being matched

column.name: MatchWID
column.comment: WID of the Protein or Subsequence matched against QueryWID

column.name: ComputationWID
column.comment: WID of the Computation that describes the procedure used to determine the match

column.name: EValue
column.comment: Roughly, the log-probability of this match occurring; see http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/BLAST/tutorial/Altschul-1.html

column.name: PValue
column.comment: 1 - e^(-E), where E is EValue

column.name: PercentIdentical
column.comment: Percentage of residues in the two molecules that are identical

column.name: PercentSimilar
column.comment: Percentage of residues in the two molecules that are similar

column.name: Rank
column.comment: Ordinal rank of Query molecule with other matches (1 is best)

column.name: Length
column.comment: The length of the match between the two molecules

column.name: QueryStart
column.comment: Start of the matching region in Query

column.name: QueryEnd
column.comment: End of the matching region in Query

column.name: MatchStart
column.comment: Start of the matching region in Match

column.name: MatchEnd
column.comment: End of the matching region in Match

table.name: Subunit
table.comment: Specifies that Subunit is a subunit of Complex. These subunit relationships could be
described in multiple levels. For example, this table can be used to describe multimeric proteins,
or ribosomes.

column.name: ComplexWID
column.comment: Reference to the parent Protein

column.name: SubunitWID
column.comment: Reference to the child protein inside the parent Protein

column.name: Coefficient
column.comment: Number of copies of the subunit within the complex

table.name: SuperPathway
table.comment: Pathways may be arranged in a hierarchy, i.e. containment within one or
more superpathways, as an abstraction mechanism.

column.name: SubPathwayWID
column.comment: WID of sub-pathway

column.name: SuperPathwayWID
column.comment: WID of super-pathway

table.name: TermRelationship
table.comment: Defines a relationship between two terms.

column.name: TermWID
column.comment: Reference to a term.

column.name: RelatedTermWID
column.comment: The WID of the term the current term is related to.

column.name: Relationship
column.comment: Enumeration.

table.name: RelatedTerm
table.comment: Defines a relationship between a term and another object. For relationships between terms, TermRelationship is generally used.

column.name: TermWID
column.comment: Reference to a term.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: The WID of the object associated with this term.

column.name: Relationship
column.comment: Enumeration.

restriction.description: The term is a keyword that characterizes the object.
The term names a class, and the object is an instance or a subclass of that class.

table.name: CitationWIDOtherWID
table.comment: Link from citations to the entities described in that citation. Enables one citation to
provide support for multiple entries in the warehouse.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: WID of the object associated with this citation

column.name: CitationWID
column.comment: WID of the Citation

table.name: CommentTable
table.comment: This table allows for arbitrary association of (possibly lengthy) comments
with any object in the warehouse.
See the Description table for a more specific type of comment.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: Warehouse id of an object

column.name: Comm
column.comment: Comment about the object

table.name: CrossReference
table.comment: This table is used to define (i) links between databases; (ii) links between objects within the same dataset.
For case (i):
A row in this table defines a link between an object in the warehouse
(OtherWID) and an entry in another dataset that may or may not be loaded
into the warehouse. If it is not loaded, DatabaseName
(and XID, Type, and Version if available) will be nonnull.
For case (ii):
A row in this table defines a link between an object in the warehouse
(OtherWID) and an object in the same dataset for which the dataset specifies
an association between them not otherwise represented within the warehouse.
Such associations are currently (5/10/04) made between a gene described in one sequence (the root Bioseq) and
another GenBank entry (the reference Bisoseq) which is being referenced and describes the gene independently
of the first Bioseq. In such a case, CrossReference.OtherWID=Gene.WID.
In either case: if CrossWID is nonnull, the object linked to is
loaded into the warehouse; if it is null, it may or may not be loaded.
Note that if a loader does not know whether a referenced entry will be loaded,
it is free to fill in CrossWID at a later time.
Restrictions: CrossReference only stores keys that point to uniquely identified objects in the referenced database.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: Warehouse object we are linking FROM

column.name: CrossWID
column.comment: Nonnull when the object we are linking TO resides in the warehouse

column.name: XID
column.comment: Unique id used in referenced database of object we are linking TO.

column.name: Type
column.comment: Enumeration: Describes the types of identifiers stored in XID, namely 'GUID' or 'Accession': GUIDs: ID's of type GUID (Globally Unique ID) are associated with database objects with one or more invariant aspects, such as a specific DNA sequence. If the invariant aspect of the database object is to change, a new GUID is assigned, and the old GUID is retired. Example: NCBI GI numbers. Accession: Database objects associated with IDs of type 'Accession' (for Accession Numbers) can change, but the Accession Number remains the same. Accession Numbers are often associated with a Version number to reflect such changes. Example: Swiss-Prot's Primary Accession Number See Enumeration table for further details.

restriction.description: Type of XID is an accession number (not guaranteed to be unique across datasets)
Type of XID is a global unique identifier (guaranteed to be unique across datasets for a given database provider)

column.name: Version
column.comment: Further qualifies the values of identifiers stored in XID by storing the version number of the identifier for datasets that support multiple instances of the same object. For example, NCBI Accession Numbers are associated with a version number, which are REQUIRED for complete identification (w/o such, different records can have the same accession number, albeit with different version numbers)

column.name: Relationship
column.comment: A short description of the relationship between the objects identified by OtherWID and CrossWID

column.name: DatabaseName
column.comment: The object we are linking TO resides in an external database of this name

table.name: Description
table.comment: This table contains a textual description of a warehouse object.
An object will not have more than one description, and the description text
will typically define or otherwise characterize the object.
See the CommentTable table for a more general type of comment.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: Warehouse id of an object

column.name: TableName
column.comment: Name of Warehouse table containing OtherWID

column.name: Comm
column.comment: Description of the object

table.name: DBID
table.comment: Associates a warehouse entity with the identifier(s) used for that entity in its
source dataset. For example, if a protein is loaded from SwissProt into the
warehouse, this table can be used to store the SwissProt accession numbers for
the protein.
Restrictions: DBID only stores keys that point to uniquely identified objects in the referenced database.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: Reference to the warehouse entity uniquely identified by this entry

column.name: XID
column.comment: Unique identifier used in dataset of entity

column.name: Type
column.comment: Enumeration: Describes the types of identifiers stored in XID, namely 'GUID' or 'Accession': GUIDs: ID's of type GUID (Globally Unique ID) are associated with database objects with one or more invariant aspects, such as a specific DNA sequence. If the invariant aspect of the database object is to change, a new GUID is assigned, and the old GUID is retired. Example: NCBI GI numbers. Accession: Database objects associated with IDs of type 'Accession' (for Accession Numbers) can change, but the Accession Number remains the same. Accession Numbers are often associated with a Version number to reflect such changes. Example: Swiss-Prot's Primary Accession Number See Enumeration table for further details.

restriction.description: Type of XID is an accession number (not guaranteed to be unique across datasets)
Type of XID is a global unique identifier (guaranteed to be unique across datasets for a given database provider)

column.name: Version
column.comment: Further qualifies the values of identifiers stored in XID by storing the version number of the identifier for datasets that support multiple instances of the same object. For example, NCBI Accession Numbers are associated with a version number, which are REQUIRED for complete identification (w/o such, different records can have the same accession number, albeit with different version numbers)

table.name: SynonymTable
table.comment: Defines one or more synonyms for a warehouse entity such as a protein, a
gene, a small molecule, or a pathway.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: Warehouse ID of an entity

column.name: Syn
column.comment: Another name for the entity

table.name: ToolAdvice
table.comment: This table captures meta-data that does not have an interpretation in
the warehouse semantics, but is `hints' to various tools that may
operate on, or build pictorial representations of, core elements of the
schema. For example, it may give hints to a particular pathway viewing
tool on how to layout a pathway.

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: The entity to which this advice applies

column.name: ToolName
column.comment: The name of the tool

column.name: Advice
column.comment: The advice

table.name: BioSourceWIDBioSubtypeWID
table.comment: Linking table which links BioSource and BioSubtype

column.name: BioSourceWID
column.comment: Links to the BioSource associated with this object.

column.name: BioSubtypeWID
column.comment: Links to the BioSubtype associated with this object.

table.name: BioSourceWIDGeneWID
table.comment: Associates a gene with those species, strains, tissues, etc, from which it was derived.

column.name: BioSourceWID
column.comment: Reference to the BioSource that has this gene.

column.name: GeneWID
column.comment: Reference to the Gene that is present in the organism.

table.name: BioSourceWIDProteinWID
table.comment: Associates a protein with those species, strains, tissues, etc, from which it was derived.

column.name: BioSourceWID
column.comment: Reference to the BioSource that has this protein.

column.name: ProteinWID
column.comment: Reference to the Protein that is present in the organism.

table.name: GeneWIDNucleicAcidWID
table.comment: Associates a gene with its nucleic acid product(s).
Note that the nucleic acid (ie. replicon) containing the gene is referenced by Gene.NucleicAcidWID,
not in this table.

column.name: GeneWID
column.comment: Reference to the Gene that produces this nucleic acid.

column.name: NucleicAcidWID
column.comment: Reference to the nucleic acid that has this gene.

table.name: GeneWIDProteinWID
table.comment: Associates a gene with its protein product(s).

column.name: GeneWID
column.comment: Reference to the Gene that produces this protein.

column.name: ProteinWID
column.comment: Reference to the protein that has this gene.

table.name: ProteinWIDFunctionWID
table.comment: Associates a non-enzymatic function with a protein that has that function.

column.name: ProteinWID
column.comment: Reference to the protein that has this function.

column.name: FunctionWID
column.comment: Reference to the function for this protein.

table.name: ExperimentRelationship
table.comment: Relates one experiment to another.
This table supports a many to many relationship.

column.name: ExperimentWID
column.comment: Experiment entity

column.name: RelatedExperimentWID
column.comment: The WID of the experiment the current term is related to

table.name: GelLocation
table.comment: Describes the location of a spot on a gel.
This tables maps spots to the one or more tables that they are found on.
Describes the X and Y coordinates on the Gel.
Information for the particular gel conditions that the spot was identified
on can be found in the Experiment table.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entity

column.name: SpotWID
column.comment: The location record is for this spot.

column.name: Xcoord
column.comment: The x-coordinate of the spot on the gel.

column.name: Ycoord
column.comment: The y-coordinate of the spot on the gel.

column.name: refGel
column.comment: Y or N.
A spot can be identified across multiple gels, so this columnn.
is used to indicate whether the X/Y coords of this particular gel was used to
determine the molecular weight and isolectric point for the spot.

column.name: ExperimentWID
column.comment: Experiment entity
Describes the gel conditions for this particular record.

column.name: DatasetWID
column.comment: The dataset the entity is from

table.name: ProteinWIDSpotWID
table.comment: Associates a spot with a known protein.
Not all spots are associated with proteins since it is not necessarily
known what the protein is for a given spot.
This table supports the ability to have a spot linked to multiple protein,
or a protein linked to multiple spots.

column.name: ProteinWID
column.comment: Reference to the protein that has been mapped to this spot.

column.name: SpotWID
column.comment: Reference to the Protein that is associated to this spot.

table.name: Spot
table.comment: Describes a spot from a 2D Gel experiment.
A spot can be linked to one or more gels and the location on the gel. The
gel location information is stored in the ExperimentData table.
A spot can be identified to be a particluar protein in the protein table
and is associated to proteins via the ProteinWIDSpotWID table
The method used to identify the spot is contained in the SpotWIDSpotIDMethodWID
table and the SpotIDMethod table.
The growth conditions for the protein is found in the ExperimentData tableeh
The Spot Name/ID goes into the SpotId row, but additional names can be stored
as DBID table entry.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entity

column.name: SpotId
column.comment: Name of the spot
Can be null

column.name: MolecularWeightEst
column.comment: Molecular weight estimated from migration on 2D gels.
Units: Daltons.

column.name: PIEst
column.comment: Isoelectric point (pI) estimated from migration on 2D gels.

column.name: DatasetWID
column.comment: The dataset the entity is from

table.name: SpotIdMethod
table.comment: Describes the method by which a spot was identified as
a particular (known) protein in the protein table.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entity

column.name: MethodName
column.comment: The name of the method
ex: Co-migration

column.name: MethodDesc
column.comment: More detailed description of method.
Ex: Co-migration with purified protein

column.name: MethodAbbrev
column.comment: A short abbreviation for the method name.
ex: C

column.name: DatasetWID
column.comment: The dataset the entity is from

table.name: SpotWIDSpotIdMethodWID
table.comment: Associates a spot with a SpotIdMethod,
which is the method used to identify a spot with a particular protein.
A spot can be identified as a particular protein by multiple methods,
so this table supports this many-to-many relationship.

column.name: SpotWID
column.comment: Reference to the2A Spot record.

column.name: SpotIdMethodWID
column.comment: Reference to the method that was used to identify a spot as a
particular protein.

table.name: NameValueType
table.comment: Represents MAGE Class NameValueType
A tuple designed to store data, keyed by a name and type.

column.name: WID

column.name: DataSetWID

column.name: Name
column.comment: MAGE attribute NameValueType.name
The name of the key.

column.name: Value
column.comment: MAGE attribute NameValueType.value
The value of the name.

column.name: Type_
column.comment: MAGE attribute NameValueType.type
The type of the key.

column.name: NameValueType_PropertySets
column.comment: Represents 1..n association between NameValueType and NameValueType
Allows nested specification of name/value pairs

column.name: OtherWID
column.comment: WID of the object this NameValueType describes

Includes MAGE Class Person

column.name: WID

column.name: DataSetWID

column.name: MAGEClass

column.name: Identifier
column.comment: MAGE attribute Identifiable.identifier
An identifier is an unambiguous string that is unique within the scope (i.e. a document, a set of related documents, or a repository) of its use.

column.name: Name
column.comment: MAGE attribute Identifiable.name
The potentially ambiguous common identifier.

column.name: URI
column.comment: MAGE attribute Contact.URI

column.name: Address
column.comment: MAGE attribute Contact.address

column.name: Phone

column.name: TollFreePhone

column.name: Email
column.comment: MAGE attribute Contact.email

column.name: Fax
column.comment: MAGE attribute Contact.fax

column.name: Parent

column.name: LastName
column.comment: MAGE attribute Person.lastName

column.name: FirstName
column.comment: MAGE attribute Person.firstName

column.name: MidInitials
column.comment: MAGE attribute Person.midInitials

column.name: Affiliation
column.comment: Represents n..1 association between Person and Organization
The organization a person belongs to.

table.name: ArrayDesign
table.comment: Represents MAGE Class ArrayDesign

Describes the design of an gene expression layout. In some cases this might be virtual and, for instance, represent the output from analysis software at the composite level without reporters or features.
Includes MAGE Class PhysicalArrayDesign

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entity

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

column.name: MAGEClass
column.comment: Discriminator column specifies type of object this row represents

column.name: Identifier
column.comment: MAGE attribute Identifiable.identifier
An identifier is an unambiguous string that is unique within the scope (i.e. a document, a set of related documents, or a repository) of its use.

column.name: Name
column.comment: MAGE attribute Identifiable.name
The potentially ambiguous common identifier.

column.name: Version
column.comment: MAGE attribute ArrayDesign.version
The version of this design.

column.name: NumberOfFeatures
column.comment: MAGE attribute ArrayDesign.numberOfFeatures
The number of features for this array

column.name: SurfaceType
column.comment: Represents 1..1 association between PhysicalArrayDesign and OntologyEntry
The type of surface from a controlled vocabulary that would include terms such as non-absorptive, absorptive, etc.

table.name: DesignElementGroup
table.comment: Represents MAGE Class DesignElementGroup
The DesignElementGroup holds information on either features, reporters, or compositeSequences, particularly that information that is common between all of the DesignElements contained.
Includes MAGE Class CompositeGroup
Includes MAGE Class FeatureGroup
Includes MAGE Class ReporterGroup

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entity

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

column.name: MAGEClass
column.comment: Discriminator column specifies type of object this row represents

column.name: Identifier
column.comment: MAGE attribute Identifiable.identifier
An identifier is an unambiguous string that is unique within the scope (i.e. a document, a set of related documents, or a repository) of its use.

column.name: Name
column.comment: MAGE attribute Identifiable.name
The potentially ambiguous common identifier.

column.name: ArrayDesign_FeatureGroups
column.comment: Represents 1..n association between ArrayDesign and FeatureGroup

The grouping of like Features together. Typically for a physical array design, this will be a single grouping of features whose type might be PCR Product or Oligo. If more than one technology type occurs on the array, such as the mixing of Cloned BioMaterial and Oligos, then there would be multiple FeatureGroups to segregate the technology types.

column.name: DesignElementGroup_Species
column.comment: Represents 1..1 association between DesignElementGroup and OntologyEntry
The organism from which the biosequences of this group are from.

column.name: FeatureWidth
column.comment: MAGE attribute FeatureGroup.featureWidth
The width of the feature.

column.name: FeatureLength
column.comment: MAGE attribute FeatureGroup.featureLength
The length of the feature.

column.name: FeatureHeight
column.comment: MAGE attribute FeatureGroup.featureHeight
The height of the feature.

column.name: FeatureGroup_TechnologyType
column.comment: Represents 1..1 association between FeatureGroup and OntologyEntry

The technology type of this design. By specifying a technology type, higher level analysis can use appropriate algorithms to compare the results from multiple arrays. The technology type may be spotted cDNA or in situ photolithography.

column.name: FeatureGroup_FeatureShape
column.comment: Represents 1..1 association between FeatureGroup and OntologyEntry
The expected shape of the feature on the array: circular, oval, square, etc.

column.name: FeatureGroup_DistanceUnit
column.comment: Represents 1..1 association between FeatureGroup and DistanceUnit
The unit for the feature measures.

table.name: Zone

Specifies the location of a zone on an array.

column.name: WID
column.comment: Warehouse identifier for this entity

column.name: DataSetWID
column.comment: Reference to the data set from which the entity came from

column.name: Identifier
column.comment: MAGE attribute Identifiable.identifier
An identifier is an unambiguous string that is unique within the scope (i.e. a document, a set of related documents, or a repository) of its use.

column.name: Name
column.comment: MAGE attribute Identifiable.name

column.name: Row_

row position in the ZoneGroup

column.name: Column_

column.name: UpperLeftX

column.name: UpperLeftY

Boundary horizontal upper left position relative to (0,0).

column.name: LowerRightX

Boundary vertical lower right position relative to (0,0).

column.name: LowerRightY

Boundary horizontal lower right position relative to (0,0).

column.name: Zone_DistanceUnit

Unit for the Zone attributes.

column.name: ZoneGroup_ZoneLocations

Describes the location of different zones within the array design.

table.name: ZoneGroup

Specifies a repeating area on an array. This is useful for printing when the same pattern is repeated in a regular fashion.

column.name: WID

column.name: DataSetWID

column.name: PhysicalArrayDesign_ZoneGroups

In the case where the array design is specified by one or more zones, allows specifying where those zones are located.

column.name: SpacingsBetweenZonesX

Spacing between zones, if applicable.

column.name: SpacingsBetweenZonesY
column.comment: MAGE attribute ZoneGroup.spacingsBetweenZonesY
